column101: The casual/informal spaces are something I didn’t even know the old office was missing, but had made a big impact on my productivity. I do a lot of work that requires focus and space and being able to get up from the desk and work in a physically different spot for an hour or two has been a big deal for my focus and overall enjoyment of the work. The barista is incredible, and frankly saves me a lot of time walking outside to a coffee place when I just need a break! It’s a beautiful building, the decor and furnishings are impeccable, and it makes me even more proud to work at BCG because I think it really shares how thoughtful and people-oriented we are as a firm. I do wish the meditation space were more inviting and less awkward — there’s one random chair, no cushions or options for sitting on the floor comfortably, and the way to use the space is unclear (do I lock the door if I’m the only one in there, do I book it just for myself, etc). column101: I love the location and parking options nearby.  You can't beat the convenience and the view!  I love the gym facilities and shower access provided.  The free coffee/tea/seltzer water are a great treat! There is great natural light in the office.  However, because everything is so open, it's like you're in a fishbowl.  I feel uncomfortable 90% of the time and I notice that people tend to be jumpy because they feel like they are always on display.  Instead of promoting collaboration, I think it promotes people to become more like hermits.  People are afraid to talk out in the open and the conference rooms are wide open so anyone can see what you are sharing in a private meeting.  I notice that a conference room will say it's open online but when I arrive, someone is sitting in there.  They are not either booking it or checking in when they arrive.  And I think this is because so many people are just seeking some privacy so they get up and walk to the nearest room.  The completely open seating with no ability to reserve a desk means that there have been times where I either don't get a desk at all or sit no where close to my team.  The alternative seating options provide terrible ergonomics and I cannot sit there for long periods of time.  Unfortunately, this has happened to me on multiple occasions as I do not believe that there are enough seats to account for everyone being in the office at the same time.  And in my section, people are in nearly every day.  It delays getting set up for your day.  Additionally, the personal lockers are too small and they should be taller to allow you to hang your jacket, bag, shoes and still allow room for files. I don't believe that the current open seating plan allows for employees to be as productive as they would like to be.

column101: The overall design, look and feel of the office are all TERRIFIC.  The care and consideration given to so many components reaffirms my belief that BCG cares about the people and the employee experience and Pier 4 largely supports that.  The teams involved in making Pier 4 an incredible place to work are best in class, truly.  We are so fortunate for the teams who support the office environment and experience. We have some improvement needed to support different types of work in GS, namely the privacy and the need for quiet zones to support thinking and work which requires analysis and review. Quiet zones and more offices and workspaces with frosted glass would be useful. The open offices to allow natural light are fit for that purpose but may have created too much visual stimulation leading to distractions in meetings and focused work. Very few offices and workstations have privacy - not all need to be completely frosted but just a bit more privacy would offset the visual stimulation created by the "fishbowl".  The monitors at workstations offer zero privacy, so when I could be working at a workstation instead of a bookable workspace, I find myself booking a resources because there is no privacy. My work absolutely requires confidentiality for many reasons. A/V equipment is top notch, needs some work to be compatible and user-friendly.  progress made in this area has been great the last few months - keep it up! I'm sad we don't have dishes to use - we are creating so much unnecessary waste, seemingly because we don't trust people to put dishes in the dishwasher.  Let's fix the culture and create personal accountability to the workspace instead of wasting money and resources on the disposable plates and utensils. Set a standard to facilitate this and signage so there are "no excuses" for not putting items in the dishwasher. Example, "Dirty dishes belong in the dishwashers to the left and right of the sink. Thank you for keeping our workspace clean". To that end, move the eating materials (cutlery and plates/bowls) to the "back kitchen" zones where the employee refrigerators are located so that we can prepare and grab food from the same area instead of needing to walk back & forth between kitchen areas, creating traffic and inefficiencies. Personal locker space should be improved. Most commute and need to change shoes, etc. - lockers are not large enough to support the Boston weather or commute options. I'd pay for extra, dedicated space which would make my am/pm feel like less of a hiking expedition and more like a normal work commute. I use my tiny locker to store the real dishes I use to eat lunch and shoes, leaving little room for anything else.  Please, please, please lobby for curtains in dressing areas in the locker rooms so we are not forced to run into half-naked colleagues - it's less than ideal on so many levels. Desk booking would be nice, given the actual desk space is limited. I don't like the notion of creating classes of citizens but seeing co-ops and temps/contractors at the workstations and working in office whilst tenured and senior folks are hunching over laptops at a barstool can be frustrating. Managers should be encouraged to set some working space norms for their teams and employee types. In light of the growth, I'm worried about future capacity for the productive workspace options.

column101: 1.Really love the barista for many reasons- great place to meet new people or meet up with coworkers for a quick break, helps break social barriers, it's high quality (I think they use local milk/organic products)- please keep high quality/sustainable products! 2. Love the stand-up sit-down desks and over-sized monitors with privacy screens- I really think the large monitors have greatly improved my efficiency at work to the point where BCG is going to start making a financial return on investment for employee efficiency. 3. Love the lighthouse staircase how it connects the three offices within BCG – that is so huge in breaking barriers and making a community feel-- Things we can work to improve—1. Can we increase our sustainability measures in the office by reducing single use serving utensils (plastic forks, cups, ect), increase recycling, buy local/organic when possible ect. 2.  I highly dislike not having a dedicated work space for many reasons including- extra time to get set up and close down every day, sterile looking and feeling work environment, no character, I want to spend less time in the office because I do not feel connected without personal touch (photos, paper calendar, plant, holiday decorations, ect). Many people sit in the same seats every day anyways which defeats part of the reason for having open seating and makes it uncomfortable for some people to sit at a work station that has been unofficially claimed by someone else. Honestly, it's very inconvenient to not have a dedicated space to work when you come into the office 5 days a week- it really makes me prefer to work from home whenever possible instead of spending over two hours total time commuting each day to have no dedicated space at the office. Can we please have an opt-in assigned work station policy for people who really want it? Maybe it’s temporary assigned stations that switch up every couple months to increase affiliation and allow for adjusting with flexing workforce size. On that topic- please increase personal and team storage space. My small locker barely fits a couple pairs of shoes and extra sweater—let alone any work materials. If we really cannot have dedicated work stations for people who come into the office 5 days a week, it would be great to at least have enough space to securely store more things so we do not have to constantly carry them back and forth on our commutes (my 2.5 hour daily commute involves multiple modes of transport due office location distance from main public transit). One last thing- the water has had an off-taste recently (like chlorine or slimy), has it been tested recently/is it safe to drink large quantities of it? Is it filtered? Can we please filter if it is not already? Thank you for your interest in our thoughts and for giving us the opportunity to provide feedback on our working environment!
